neighborhoods.name: Chelsea
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: Chelsea is one of Manhattan's most vibrant neighborhoods, with excellent subway access via the 8th Avenue and 7th Avenue lines. The neighborhood is home to world-class galleries, the iconic High Line park, and Chelsea Market.

neighborhoods.name: SoHo
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: SoHo, short for South of Houston, features cobblestone streets lined with cast-iron architecture. Multiple subway lines make it easy to reach this shopping and arts destination.

neighborhoods.name: Tribeca
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: Tribeca (Triangle Below Canal Street) transformed from industrial warehouses to one of NYC's most prestigious neighborhoods. Home to celebrities and the famous film festival.

neighborhoods.name: Midtown
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: Midtown Manhattan is the commercial heart of NYC, home to iconic landmarks, Broadway theaters, and the busiest subway stations in the system.

neighborhoods.name: Upper West Side
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: The Upper West Side is a classic residential neighborhood bordering Central Park, known for brownstones, cultural institutions, and excellent schools.

neighborhoods.name: Financial District
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: The Financial District is where New York began and remains the economic engine of the city. Historic sites blend with modern skyscrapers above busy subway stations.

neighborhoods.name: Williamsburg
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: Williamsburg has transformed from industrial waterfront to cultural hotspot. The L train on Bedford Avenue is the neighborhood's lifeline to Manhattan.

neighborhoods.name: DUMBO
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: DUMBO (Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass) offers stunning views of Manhattan and the Brooklyn Bridge, with cobblestone streets and converted warehouse spaces.

neighborhoods.name: Park Slope
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: Park Slope is one of Brooklyn's most desirable neighborhoods, featuring beautiful brownstones, proximity to Prospect Park, and a thriving family community.

neighborhoods.name: Bushwick
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: Bushwick is Brooklyn's arts and nightlife hub, known for vibrant street art, creative studios, and an eclectic dining scene. The L and J/M/Z trains connect to Manhattan.

neighborhoods.name: Astoria
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: Astoria is Queens' most diverse neighborhood, offering authentic cuisines from Greek to Egyptian. The N/W trains provide a quick commute to Midtown.

neighborhoods.name: Long Island City
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: Long Island City has evolved into a waterfront destination with stunning Manhattan skyline views, world-class art institutions, and excellent transit connections.

neighborhoods.name: Jackson Heights
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: Jackson Heights is one of NYC's most ethnically diverse neighborhoods, with Little India, Little Colombia, and cuisines from around the world. The 7 train is its main artery.

neighborhoods.name: Flushing
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: Flushing is home to one of the largest Chinatowns outside Asia. The 7 train terminus at Main Street is one of the busiest stations outside Manhattan.

neighborhoods.name: South Bronx
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: The South Bronx is the birthplace of hip-hop culture and home to Yankee Stadium. The area is experiencing revitalization while maintaining its cultural heritage.

neighborhoods.name: Fordham
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: Fordham is a bustling Bronx neighborhood centered around Fordham Road, one of the borough's main shopping corridors. It's near top attractions like the Bronx Zoo.

neighborhoods.name: Harlem
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: Harlem is the cultural capital of Black America, rich in history from the Harlem Renaissance to today. Multiple subway lines connect this vibrant neighborhood to all of NYC.

neighborhoods.name: East Village
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: The East Village retains its counterculture spirit while evolving into a diverse residential area. It's a hub for nightlife, restaurants, and creative energy.

neighborhoods.name: Lower East Side
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: The Lower East Side is steeped in immigrant history while hosting cutting-edge galleries and nightlife. Historic delis stand alongside modern boutiques.

neighborhoods.name: Greenwich Village
neighborhoods.editorialIntro: Greenwich Village is where Bob Dylan played, the LGBTQ+ rights movement began, and NYU students study. Its tree-lined streets and cultural history make it quintessentially NYC.
